title: Dasaki Kinect2 (One) USB 3.0 / DC breakout connector adapter

description.text:
A connector to plug the Kinect 2 sensor to a computer USB 3.0 port and power plug (12v) BOARDS ARE MIRRORED, as they are intended for toner transfer.
Boards' footprint is about 19x19 mm
Boards are 1mm thick Connections as explained here: http://openkinect.org/wiki/Kinect_2
Useful info also here: http://www.tatsch-it.de/kinect-2-usb-3-modification Disclaimer: this is a work in progress and has not been tested yet!
I'm not responsible for any loss, problem or damage on anyone's device or equipment. EDIT (28/01/2018): changed the license to GNU - GPL If you are a curious maker / "tinker" / hacker, have a look at my blog:
www.therandomlab.com

• Print the 3D pieces in PLA, 0.2mm maximum layer height.
  • Cleanup the prints removing any imperfections.
  • Etch the boards in 1mm PCB and sand the edges until they fit on the printed plug piece (you will need two units of the "board_1"). Then drill the boards through the plugs holes.
  • Add a generous amount of solder tin to the boards paths and sand the tin, so all the kinect's pins make a good contact.
  • Check if the boards still fit well on the plug after adding the tin.
  • Solder the USB and DC wires.
  • Insert the boards on the plug and check everything is working.
  • If all is okay, put the covers on the plug sliding them and secure it with M3x20mm screws and nuts.

description.text: inspired by Carasibana's great Super Game PiSP and it's root: adafruit's super DIY Raspberry Pi Gameboy

notable changes:
  • designed around a different set of components
  • modular = easier to modify (e.g: just change the switch carrier if your using different sized switches), and easy to design new side-wings
  • body usable stand-alone
  • more ergonomic controller pad/sides (curved backside)
  • as few screws visible as possible (only 4!)
  • covered usb and ethernet ports; hidden behind separate flaps
BOM:

• watterott 5" touch display
  • short hdmi and micro-usb cable to connect the display-driver with the raspberry (both trimmed to length)
  • alps 4-way navigation switch
  • colored switches for A B X and Y (reichelt.de : "DT 6 RT", "DT 6 BL", "DT 6 GE", "DT 6 GN")
  • tiny tactile switches (reichelt.de : "Taster 9302")
  • pieces of ~1mm diameter wire for the shoulder-button and rear-flap axle
  • countersunk M3x10
  • optional: self-threading screws to secure the switch-carriers and the tft bracket
Assembly:

parts that need to be glued together:
  • body_backplate + body_backplate_sliders (mind the slanted edge on the later, they go topside-on-topside)
  • bodyframe*
  • bodytft* + pody_raspberry_support
  • body_rear_base + ODD numbered bodyrear*
  • right_buttoncarrier*
    • other:
  • the even numbered bodyrear* are inserted inbetween the odd num bered, with a straight piece of wire as the hinge
  • sand; paint; enjoy :-)
Software

• Raspbian as base OS
  • Retro-Pi, installed via the setup script
  • which in turn gives you emulationstation as UI
  • adafruits retrogame to hook up the push-buttons directly to the gpios of the raspberry
NOTE:

• the body frame is designed to be slim, so the pinheader pins 1-10 had to go :'-( (either desolder, or trim them... or design a backplate with a bump in it)
  • batteries not included - at least not yet, there is still room though

title: Nexus 5 Vertical Tripod Mount for creating 360° Photo Spheres

description.text:
Created to better shoot 360° Photo Spheres from a Tripod with my Nexus 5.  
It has a plastic screw thread, which worked perfectly with my tripod but might not be suited for frequent swapping.

I printed it in PET material and high infill for extra strength. Needs no supports.  
For a snug fit with the phone: put a business card between the phone's back and the mount.

This is my first publication, hope you gonna enjoy it...

  • enjoy their wide-open eyes ;-)

This is a filament winder to go with a home extruder like the Filastruder. The filament drops into a loop and comes back up to the winder. At the bottom are a pair of photo resistors and a laser which monitor the position of the loop and speed up or slow down the winder so it stays in sync with the extruder. The filament is pulled up with a pinch roller based on the Minimalistic Extruder, then runs over a spring loaded arm. The arm is mounted on a potentiometer, and its position depends on how tight the spool is pulling the filament. Using the reading of the potentiometer, the spool speeds up or slows down as needed to maintain the arm's position, and therefore tension. On the way to the spool, the filament passes through a guide arm which is attached to a servo. Hall effect sensors detect the rotation of the spool and move the guide over the space of 1 filament diameter so the filament gets coiled evenly across the spool. The spool mount is a PVC pipe with bearings inside supported on a threaded rod, with a gear on the end. The spool itself is made from 2 printed ends fitted into a 2" PVC pipe, so it would be easy to make spools as needed. The spool simply slides onto the mount and mates with some bolts sticking out of the side of the gear. The winder is powered by an Arduino Uno with a half breadboard, mounted in this bracket - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32838. Eventually I want to replace the breadboard with a custom shield. Here are some videos of the winder at various stages- http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=En3bWu_PNB4
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1snEOnw5JKE
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JSWfQLsiL4M
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7YpmDGL4AoE

The instructions are too involved for Thingiverse, so I am posting them at my blog, starting with http://wp.me/p2BWKW-9q. Most of the files are here, and are mostly current, but a couple still need to change and be added. I don't have a detailed BOM down to size and quantity of the bolts, but there should be enough there to get you started. I will host the files here and update them, and keep posting about the build at the blog. Files and instructions are works in progress so I recommend following both.

comments.text: Can you explain why you used two hall effect sensors instead of one?  Trying to understand if I can get away with one
comments.author: datasmasher

comments.text: The sensor gets polled quickly enough that after a rotation is detected, the sensor would be checked again and another rotation counted before the magnet has had the time to move out of range.  With two sensors, a new rotation won't be noted unless both sensors have been triggered since the last rotation.   You can get by with one sensor if you just make it wait long enough for the magnet to move away before it starts checking again.  That can take a little time if the spool is moving very slowly due to being full.  I'd like to be able to use the winder to wind up coils or transfer between spools and in those cases you might want to spin it very fast by hand or with a drill.  In that case the delay before rechecking might be slow enough to miss a rotation at high speed.
comments.author: datasmasher

comments.text: Make sense.  I noticed the sensor detecting the magnet for a long period of time.  I might try adding a function to the Arduino code to ignore the magnet for a period, or I might just add the second sensor.  Need to dig through my parts and see if I have another sensor...

title: Handle for Spatula, Spoon, Lattle, or anything.

description.text: Handle for Spatula, Spoon, Lattle, or anything.

I printed mine at .25 layer with 3 shells and 10% infill.  Scale the print so the handle is 4.5 to 5.5 inches(personal prefference).   
When done I filed away some of the inner area at the handle enterance for a tight fight. I dug out enough infill to insert the handl 1.5 to 2 inches. I prepped the spatula handle area to be inserted by drilling a hole throught it around 1/8 inch dia. That hole will be the mechanical link when the glue sets. So keep it near the end.   
When everything was fitted I put a fair amount of Gorilla Glue(the kind that expands) in the printed handle hole and made sure all the fitted parts had a coating. I had prewrapped the spatula handle with tape to the insertion depth line. Once together I mount it in a vice(cover with tape) with the handle up. I tape braced in straight and vertical. Then I did not move it for 16 hours. After that I cleaned up the excess glue with a file.  
That was a year ago and it's still going strong.

title: Smoothieboard X5 v1.0a frame for MakerFarm i3v

description.text: This is a mounting plate and case for a Smoothieboard v1.0a electronics board. The mount is optimized for use on a MakerFarm i3/i3v printer, using the RAMPS mounting holes provided on the wood frame of the MakerFarm i3v. The high mounting location leaves space on the printer frame sidewall for other electronics like a Raspberry Pi. This frame design will have the USB, SD card and ethernet connectors oriented towards the rear of the printer, the motor connectors oriented down, and the bulk of the MOSFET switch connections on the top. This seemed to be the best orientation for use with the MakerFarm 8-inch i3v printer. The design provided is optimized for an X5 board purchased without connectors. Due to their small size, Euro-style screw terminal blocks were used for all power and MOSFET switch connector locations. To ease wire installation and ensure solid connections, contact pins, R/C hobby EC2 connector contacts, or crimp sleeves were used on all wires connecting to screw terminals. Mounting posts are provided for use with cable clamps. Large vent holes are provided for cooling. Should active cooling be necessary, vent holes on the back side or the lid could be replaced by mounts for small fans. Holes are provided in the lid for GLCD ribbon cables assuming use of the Uberclock Smoothieboard GLCD shield. Gallery pictures show the Smoothieboard mount used with the Printbus GLCD mount available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:817274. This design is a heavily tailored version of Generic Case and Lid - Improved by Printbus (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643264) which is a remix of Generic case (box and lid) by davidmpye (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28608). It leverages the polyhole and teardrop modules from the openSCAD MCAD library. It also leverages roundCornersCube available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812, and my universal post available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790359. For fit check purposes, the openSCAD file has provisions for previewing STL models of the Smoothieboard available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:290180 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:414426. The frame was built for use on an 8-inch MakerFarm i3v printer purchased in April 2014. On at least that printer, the RAMPS mounting holes on the wood frame seemed to be a bit off and were modified for proper RAMPS fitment. The RAMPS hole pattern used in the design reflects dimensioning for the Arduino MEGA2560 board, not the incorrect hole placements observed on the i3v printer.

The openSCAD file provides numerous parameters that can be tailored by the user, based on the amount of inset clearance desired between the board edges and the box of the frame, and then the amount of outset desired from the box walls to the edge of mounting lips provided on the frame.

A co-worker asked if it was possible to print a wasp trap with my RepStrap and like any good operator I said absolutely.  I did a little research and settled on a type of trap that I thought would be most printable and designed this.
It is a two part trap that allows you to easily clean out the dead wasps and reset the trap.  I reccomend printing it with clear or translucent PLA so you can see the dead wasps as they fill the trap, just make sure they are dead when you empty the trap or you'll probably free a bunch of pissed off wasps and that can't be good.

• Print both sections of the trap.

  • Soak a cotton ball in fruit juice or soda.

  • Assemble trap by twisting the base onto the lid.

  • Thread a string through the hole at the top of the trap and hang.

I use ping pong balls cut in half as FPV antenna protection.
For this purpose I have designed 3D-printed lowers that fit the kind of 3 and 4 winged antennas sold on EBay and many other places. The antennas are pretty generic and should fit a lot of other types too. The lowers are secured to the ping pong halves by some dabs of thin super glue around the edge. The antennas do not have to be glued in place. A quick tip: It is quite easy to give white balls some color by dissolving the ink from dried permanent marker pens in some rubbing alcohol and then dipping the ball halves in the spirits.

title: Firefly Serenity Extra Large Snap-Fit Model

description.text:
I wanted to make an extra large model, and decided to use pins to connect the pieces together instead of using glue.   
Total size is about 13" x 9".  
I can get about 115mm in the X axis and 120mm in the Z axis with my TOM, and this model was scaled up to the max my machine will support.  
I cut the model up with NetFabb, then used Blender3D to create sockets for the pins.

I print in PLA, and had no issues with printing without a raft. However, if you're printing in ABS or you tend to get curling, you may want to consider printing a raft as well. especially on this models that go all the way up to the edge of the bed. All parts printed with 1 shell and 5% infill, except for the pins. Part1: Full Supports
Part 2a: External Supports
Part 2b: External Supports
Part 3a: No Supports
Part 3b: No Supports
Part 4: External Supports
Pins: 1 Shell, 50% infill Part 1 was a bit difficult to clean all the supports, but have a thin file helped greatly. Don't push the pins in too hard -- I accidentally pushed one all the way through inside the model. If it doesn't fit, either scale the pins down slightly, or try to enlarge the holes a bit with a file or blade.

comments.text: In case you guys are wondering....I've stopped using rafts on a lot of things and gone to wonderful, beautiful Aquanet.  I use the "All Weather" version that is fragrance free.  While the bed is hot, shoot the bed with a coat and fire up the printer.  Whatever you print will stick nice and hard and not curl up.  And I do mean stick!  My bed is covered by Kapton and the Kapton does not come up with a use a spatula to remove the print.  Just awesome.....
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: I've been doing the same.  Easiest way to remove well-stuck large prints is to put the bed in the freezer for a few minutes - the plastic and glass cool at different rates, and the part pops right off on its own.  I learned this the hard way after a very large part (~11" x 8") wouldn't let go and I cracked my bed trying to pry it loose.  Now every print visits the freezer!
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: You can also just turn a can of air upside down and shoot the part with a bit of it.  It comes out super cold this way and causes a quick but brief contraction of the plastic and the part usually pops right off.
Very nice! I'll be printing this!
comments.author: laird

comments.text:
Shiny!

comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I wanted something that didn't require any extra hardware. Everything here is printed from the printer. I have no idea what glue plastic models typically use. I'm sure a lot of people don't either. This model design is solely sufficient on just the printer.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: Awesome work! Pins are a great idea, though if you ever do want to use glue, typical model superglue (the kind you find in hobby shops that sell miniatures) will work equally well with ABS or PLA, as will standard acrylic model paints. There is some major appeal to making something that's finished right off the plate, of course.

A small recurve bow riser and limbs I designed to be printed on my Printrbot Simple Metal.  Meant to be assembled with ~20mm M3 screws and nuts.  Gluing with solvent would also work, or even zip ties come to think of it.

I printed mine in PLA at 0.2mm layer height, but I think ABS or some other material that has better interlayer adhesion would likely work better.  Support is optional for the riser but isn't needed for the limbs.  Print the riser on it's side.  Print 2 limbs also on their sides.  
Attach the limbs to the riser with nuts/bolts, solvent glue, zip ties or whatever else you have lying around.

description.text: This was a suggestion posted in the Star Wars thingiverse group and I thought I would give it a shot. A very simple version of Vader's lightsaber with an oval cavity at the top to slide a BIC disposable lighter into. The cavity should be just deep enough to still allow the metal head of the lighter (housing the striker and gas valve button) to be easily accessible. 2/23/16 edit added a requested "mini" version that is only slightly larger than a standard BIC lighter. This one measures 3.68inches (93.48mm) from end to end. Also adjusted the lighter cavity on the original so it wouldn't be such a tight fit.

author: bensoncte

description.text:
A firepit for 28mm Heroic Scale RPGs such as D&D.  It should fit into a 2x2 inch square, ideal for bonfires in goblin villages. Scale down by 50% for a 1-square campfire.  
The picture shows one print at 100% size, .2mm layer height, and a small one at 50% size, .1mm layer height. It doesn't matter much for the flames, but the stones benefit from lower layer heights a lot. Both models are painted with acrylic paints.  
Remixed from two existing designs. I seriously just plopped them down together and saved. Nothing fancy here.

comments.text: There are some internal voids that should be solid resulting in serious print issues. I would suggest the designer make all the stones solid and let the slicer reduce infill % for material savings.
comments.author: Falk3r

description.text:
This is my custom delta printer.
I tried to make a mix between Rostock and Delta-PI to keep it relatively cheap, easy to source, silent but still a good print quality. The printer isn't finished yet, so the exact number of components may change.
The picture is a Quick&Dirty prototype.

BOM Hardware : 28xM3 30mm screws. 14xM3 20mm screws. 40xM3 washers. 42xM3 nuts. 12xM6 40mm hexagonal head screws. 3xM6 20mm hexagonal head screws. 30xM6 washers. 15xM6 nuts. 6x500mm 8mm smooth-rod. 10mm MDF. 6x180mm of 4mm diameter rod (I use aluminum rod). BOM Bearings, belts and pulleys : 6xLM8UU linear bearing (optional) 3x18 tooth MXL pulley. 3x626 bearings. 3x1560mm MXL 2.032 mm pitch belt. (same as Rostock) BOM Electronics : 3xNEMA 17. A controller (I use my Smoothieboard)
Replica of the Bely Buckle movie prop from The Phantom.
bracelet
Replica of the Phantom Ring movie prop from The Phantom.
Green spider :D

My wife picked up a replacement adjustable screen for our sliding glass door, but unfortunately the wheels that came with it were too small to reach the top and bottom of the track. After being annoyed that the door barely opened and closed by sliding metal against metal I figured maybe I could just print replacements. Thankfully a little time in Sketchup and and printing solved my problem! I made the wheels big enough to reach the top and bottom tracks and now the door works great!   
For installation, I drilled holes for the axles near the original wheels and used a heated leather working tool to melt both ends of the axles in place.
I printed each part in PLA (although Nylon would be better for wear) using a 0.6mm nozzle. I also used 2 shells, 3 solid top and bottom layers, and 60% infill for strength.

comments.text: Best to print this in Taulman Nylon or ABS, PLA does tend to soften and deform from the heat of the sun.
comments.author: mb20music

comments.text: Totally; in fact I was hoping to print it out of Nylon I just haven't been able to order a spool of it yet though. Once I do the plan is replace the wheels, well... if they start to break or warp that is. Part of me wonders how the standard MakerGeeks PLA will handle the weathering.
comments.author: mb20music

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Double Hinged 12864 Full Graphics LCD Frame

title: RRD 128x64 GLCD mount & frame for MakerFarm i3v with Smoothieboard

description.text: This consists of a compact case and mountable hinge for the GLCD Full-Graphic display module by RepRapDiscount. The hinged mount is intended for use with the MakerFarm i3v printer consisting of a wood frame and aluminum v-rail channels. The hinge mounts to the electronics side of the i3v frame by replacing the uppermost M5x12 v-rail attachment screw with a longer M5x16 screw. An optional second mounting hole is provided for those wishing to drill another hole in the printer frame and in possession of another M5 nut plate. This mounting location on the i3v allows the use of minimal-length ribbon cables between the GLCD and the printer electronics, and allows those ribbon cables to be isolated from other printer wiring. Note that the GLCD mount is intended to be used with the Printbus MakerFarm i3v Smoothieboard frame at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:816676. Due to physical conflicts, it is not compatible with the RAMPS electronics installed on the MakerFarm 8-inch i3v printer. Compatibility with other MakerFarm printer sizes or with other electronic suites is unknown. The hinge consists of two pivot arms interconnected with an M4 screw, spring, and M4 locknut. Orientation ridges in the pivot arms assist the hinge in self-orienting to 0 and 90 degrees. The spring allows the hinge to rotate through the orientation ridges while also providing pressure on the ridges in holding orientation. The hinged mount allows the GLCD to rotate rearward for side viewing, storage, or for forward-facing access to the GLCD SD card reader. The GLCD case mounts to the hinge with a single M4x40 (or longer) screw and an M4 locknut captured in the GLCD case. The single-bolt connection between the hinge and the GLCD case provides for an adjustable vertical viewing angle of the GLCD screen. Adding a thin mylar or similar shim between the hinge and the GLCD case will ensure smooth rotation of the viewing angle. Optional spacers can be printed for use in ensuring proper spacing between the GLCD circuit boards as mounting screws are tightened. An optional rear panel cover is provided for use with the GLCD case. While holes in the GLCD circuit boards accept up to M3 hardware, the case is intended for use with M2.5 screws to allow some flexibility in aligning screws with engagement holes at the front of the case. M2.5x12 screws with washer are recommended if no rear panel is used. M2.5x16 screws without washer are recommended if the rear panel is used. The GLCD Mount for MakerFarm i3v is a heavily modified remix of Double Hinged 12864 Full Graphics LCD Frame (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:626307) by enif. Revisions include general fitment improvements, file structure and commenting for understandability, providing more encoder shaft exposure for knob compatibility, hinge redesign for rotation to the rear instead of downwards, mount modifications for use with MakerFarm i3v printers, added provisions for the rear cover.

The GLCD assembly should be inspected for proper alignment between circuit boards.  The Printbus GLCD required some force to twist the boards into a close enough alignment that screws could pass straight through the rear cover, both boards, and into the front panel.   
Length of the screws used to attach the GLCD to the front panel is critical. Too long or too much tightening will cause the screws to bulge or burst through the front panel.  
I didn't feel a spring was necessary on the rotation joint between the hinge mount and the GLCD frame.  I did include a mylar washer between the two and simply tightened the bolt until the rotation angle would hold.  
The length of M4 bolt required for the 0/90 hinge depends on the length of spring used.  I'm currently using an M4x40 screw.   
Used with Smoothieware, the tactile pushbutton can be configured for a number of uses.  To make it more useable, I replaced the OEM short stem switch with a longer one that sticks through the front panel of the frame.  I used a TE Connectivity part number 2-1825910-7 switch with a 9mm stem from Mouser.

description.text:
Labels for herbs  
Made to be used with a clip or cable tie

There is a single stl for each label.  
To get two colour print I merely change extruder when reaching layers for the letters, which would be layer 5 if printing with 0,2mm layer thickness (and bottom layer is 0).  
Base plate is 0,8mm and letters are 0,8 mm. I will recommend using same colour for base plate+1 letter layer, so the new colour does not smear of on the base plate.  
Of cause you can print with just one colour if you like.

I really like this body (great work man) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42772 so i decided to make a "rail" to add on things like what Flight Test did on the new multicopters. This fits on the front and uses the 2 front holes as anchors, you will need a 6mm longer 3m bolts than usual. Feel free to design remixes of this, or attachments for it, like camera mounts and gimble hangers.

this is my thoughts of those professional-looking cable chains as found at the big industry roboters... it's meant to be mounted at the right side of the y-stage (instead of the x-rods end plates). unfortunatelly the chain links are a bit too small to fit the x-cables (the ones for the build paltform plus the one to the x-endstop) into :-(
the 'cabin' thing where the y-moving chains are sliding inside is a bit tight as well...
-- so consider it as a proof of concept only! I included all the files needed to build those - just in case anyone want to derive from this - any comments much appreciated!
(don't look too close at the Inventor files - those are real messy right now as I am far from being an Inventor specialist...)

DO NOT PRINT - those won't actually work - as said above!
1.) the chain links are too small to fit the cables into...
2.) the 'cabin' thing is too tight (the chain links are moving inside but not as easy as they should)
(the chain itself actually is working pretty well: rotating quite easily without falling apart - proper skeinforge settings assumed) the ideas of assembling this mount together and/or using the skeinforge 'multiply' option for printing raftless many identically items at once (on a perfectly levelled platform of course -- I actually made 36 at once and even could've added another row; the right-side gap is caused by the whiper and sadly cannot be avoided) might inspire some other maker, so I posted it nevertheless... I will re-design that thing with some bigger dimensions and eventually position the mount not at the right side but above (as replacement of the x-endstop plate) - seems more space there... I could of course reuse my many printed chain-links for the left side of the y-stage - those few cables (for the x-stepper) should fit there.. if you're interested, just have a look here at thingiverse - I don't specify this as a 'Work in Progress' and will make a derivate of it instead; that's because I expect just too many changes until it actually WILL work... [Update]
see the last picture as reference for how the cable was meant to be hold in place (these little bastards came out pretty ugly, I should have placed them on the sides i.s.o. the front of the main chain-links bodies - have to experiment with that)

author: Jippe01

description.text:
I had trouble finding a replacement for an old ceilng lamp cup (don't exactly know if this is the right name for it) after the original one got broken, and so I printed myself one...  
I don't know if this design will be of any use to anyone else, but since it solved a problem for me, perhaps it will help someone else as well.  
UPDATE: Added a couple of pictures of the cup in its final placement!

I printed it in 0.2mm layers on my Arduino Materia 101, in white PLA.  
Assembly is very simple, slide the small cone on the wire, then slide the cup, and make the electric connections. Once done, push cone and cup towards the ceilng until the cup rests flat on the ceiling, and tighten the grub screw slightly (don't over-tighten as you might damage the rubber coating of the wire).  
The small cone that helps hold the cup on the wire requires a 3mm grub screw, and is designed to fit on a wire that is 6mm in diameter.  
Please note that electric connections involve a certain amount of risk, and should only be done by professionals, and in any case always after powering of the mains switch!!!
